prior_works.title: Efficiently Modeling Long Sequences with Structured State Spaces (S4)
prior_works.authors: Albert Gu, Karan Goel, Christopher Ré
prior_works.role: Foundational SSM architecture linking linear state-space recurrences to parallel convolution with structured transitions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM inherits the SSM formulation and efficiency goals of S4, but replaces S4’s specific structure with a P·D factorization to recover automata-like expressivity while retaining diagonal-SSM-level compute.

prior_works.title: HiPPO: Recurrent Memory with Optimal Polynomial Projections
prior_works.authors: Albert Gu, Karan Goel, Christopher Ré
prior_works.role: Stability and discretization blueprint for SSMs with complex-valued spectra
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM’s use of complex-valued diagonal dynamics and its BIBO-stability analysis follow the stability/discretization principles popularized by HiPPO-based SSMs.

prior_works.title: Mamba: Linear-Time Sequence Modeling with Selective State Spaces
prior_works.role: Scan-based linear-time inference for SSMs and hardware-efficient implementations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM leverages the same parallel-scan paradigm emphasized by Mamba, showing that its sparse P·D transition keeps scan cost linear in state size while improving expressivity.

prior_works.title: MONARCH: Expressive Structured Matrices for Efficient Transformers
prior_works.authors: Tri Dao, Beidi Chen, Atri Rudra, Christopher Ré
prior_works.role: Structured matrix design using products of permutations and (block-)diagonals for fast multiplies with low memory
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM’s transition as a product of a column-one-hot (permutation-like) matrix and a diagonal matrix directly echoes Monarch-style permute–diagonal factorizations to achieve expressivity with linear-time multiplies.

prior_works.title: Weighted finite-state transducers in speech recognition
prior_works.authors: Mehryar Mohri, Fernando Pereira, Michael Riley
prior_works.role: Formal WFA/WFST framework clarifying state transitions as weighted linear operators
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM’s FSA-tracking view maps naturally onto the WFST formalism, with P encoding next-state routing and D encoding transition weights, grounding its automata emulation claims.

prior_works.title: Linear automaton transformations
prior_works.role: Automata minimality theory (Myhill–Nerode) establishing optimal number of states
prior_works.relationship_sentence: PD-SSM’s proof that it emulates any N-state FSA with optimal state size relies on Myhill–Nerode-style minimality, tying its dimension guarantees to classical automata theory.

prior_works.title: Spectral Learning of Weighted Automata
prior_works.authors: Borja Balle, Xavier Carreras, Ariadna Quattoni
prior_works.role: Linear-algebraic representation and learning of weighted automata via Hankel/spectral methods
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By viewing automata transitions as linear maps, this work underpins PD-SSM’s construction of transition operators (P·D) that realize WFA behavior within an SSM layer.

synthesis_narrative:
PD-SSM targets the core tension in state-space models between computational efficiency and expressivity. S4 established the modern SSM blueprint—linear recurrences discretized from continuous-time dynamics with structured transition operators that enable parallel convolution—while HiPPO provided stability and complex-eigenvalue machinery that made such discretizations robust. Mamba advanced this line with hardware-friendly, linear-time scan-based inference, showing state updates can be parallelized without sacrificing sequential fidelity. PD-SSM embraces these efficiency and stability pillars but rethinks the transition matrix: instead of dense or purely diagonal structures, it uses a product of a column one-hot (routing/permutation-like) matrix and a complex diagonal, achieving the O(n)-per-scan cost characteristic of diagonal SSMs.

This P·D parameterization draws directly on the structured-matrix literature typified by Monarch, where alternating permutation and diagonal factors yield expressive yet fast linear maps. Crucially, PD-SSM links SSM dynamics to automata theory: the WFST/WFA perspective (Mohri–Pereira–Riley) casts state transitions as weighted linear operators; spectral WFA results (Balle–Carreras–Quattoni) further ground their linear-algebraic realization; and Myhill–Nerode minimality justifies the claim of optimal state size for tracking N-state FSAs. The result is an SSM layer that preserves diagonal-level compute and stability while restoring the discrete state-tracking power of finite automata via a sparse, permutation–diagonal transition—providing provable expressive guarantees and practical parallelism.
